title: 115_s2266
content: The Act titled the "Abby Honold Act" establishes a demonstration program for trauma-informed training for law enforcement. The "Abby Honold Act" defines key terms such as "Attorney General" and "covered individual" as individuals who work with victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. It also defines "demonstration site" as the area over which an eligible entity receiving a grant has jurisdiction. The "Abby Honold Act" defines "eligible entity" as a law enforcement agency or victim services organization working with law enforcement. The Attorney General awards grants to these entities on a competitive basis. The demonstration program under the "Abby Honold Act" provides grants to eligible entities to implement trauma-informed techniques for preventing re-traumatization of victims, improving communication between victims and law enforcement, and increasing collaboration among stakeholders. The "Abby Honold Act" demonstration program aims to increase collaboration among stakeholders in addressing domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Attorney General will evaluate the effectiveness of the training process by measuring investigative and prosecutorial practices, as well as the well-being and satisfaction of victims with the criminal justice process. Grants will be awarded to eligible entities for the first 2 fiscal years after the Act's enactment. The grant program aims to train individuals in various communities to use trauma-informed techniques in investigating domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking. The training includes conducting victim interviews to gather valuable information. The grant program trains individuals in communities to use trauma-informed techniques in investigating cases of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking. This includes conducting field investigations using best practices, customizing approaches for cultural sensitivity, and responding to complex cases involving alcohol or drugs, strangulation, or non-stranger perpetrators. The grant program focuses on training individuals in communities to investigate cases of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking. This includes developing collaborative relationships between law enforcement officers, response team members, and the community being served. It also involves understanding how to define, identify, and correctly classify reports of violence, including cases involving non-stranger perpetrators, same-sex individuals, victims with disabilities, male victims, and LGBT victims. The grant program aims to train individuals in communities to investigate cases of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking. It involves promoting efforts to improve the response of covered individuals through various communication channels and trainings on trauma-informed approaches for law enforcement officers. The grant program focuses on training individuals in communities to investigate cases of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking using trauma-informed approaches. Eligible entities receiving grants must select approaches from identified trainings to test within demonstration sites. The Attorney General consults with the Director of the Office for Victims of Crime to gather input on trauma-informed care for victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Each grant recipient must partner with a research entity to design a system for data collection and evaluation. The Attorney General must design a system for data collection and evaluation to assess the impact of grant funds. Periodic evaluations and public release of results and recommendations are required.
